helpText.desc: Controls the base range in which objects will be pushed away. Also affected by object scale.
Controls how much force to push objects. It is modified by strength modifiers.
Rename this character.
Set how far this light shines (only available for lights).
Fine tune the speed of this bot. A value of 1.0 will match the default speed.
Fine tune the acceleration of this bot. A value of 1.0 will match the default acceleration.
Add a helmet to this character.
Lock this bot's position so it can't move in any direction. It can still rotate.
Makes this bot indestructible.
When set, a small bar will appear over the top of the head of this bot indicating how much health the bot has remaining.
This lets you control the starting number of hit points this bot has. The number of hit points will then go down as the bot is damaged and up when it is healed.

When a bot is marked as "Creatable" it then becomes special in two ways. First, if you clone this bot then all the clones will share the same brain - changes to one will change them all. You can see the link between creatables and their clones as dotted lines (when editing.) Second, you can now program other bots to Create this bot complete with its programming. This is great for arcade games where you want to continuously create enemies. Note that this can make it easy to overrun the world's budget at which point Create will stop working.

For creatables, this count limits the number that can be created during gameplay. Clones that you spread about while editing don't count, this just limits the number that can be spawned by other bots with Create while playing.

Controls how the camera acts with regard to this bot. Normally the camera will follow any bot that is controlled by a player. If you set this to Always then the camera will always follow this bot. If you have more than one bot with this set then the camera will try and keep them all on screen. If you set this to Never then the camera will ignore this bot even if it is user controlled.
This controls how far away a "held" object is carried.
This controls how bouncy a bot is when colliding the the terrain, walls, or other bots.
This controls how much a bot slides when colliding the the terrain, walls, or other bots.
Controls how much damage a blip fired from this bot causes.
The blip reload time controls long after a bot fires a blip before it can fire again. This is measured in seconds.
Controls how far blips can travel before disappearing.
Controls how fast blips fired from this bot travel.
Controls how many blips this bot can have in the air at once. Once the bot has fired this number, it can't fire again until some blips have either hit something or reached their maximum range.
Controls how many Hit Points a missile fired from this bot damages a target when hit.
Controls how long a bot has to wait between firing missiles. This is measured in seconds.
Controls how far missiles can travel before disappearing.
Controls how fast missiles fired from this bot travel.
Controls how many missiles this bot can have in the air at once. Once the bot has fired this number, it can't fire again until some missiles either hit something or reach their maximum range.
Controls whether missiles fired by this bot emit smoke. Missiles with no smoke are faster to render.
Controls whether the shield visual effect is displayed when this bot hits something or takes damage.
Controls whether this bot is displayed at all. Can still be seen and heard by other bots.
Controls whether this bot can be seen, heard and bumped by other bots. Ghost bots can still see and hear others, but can't bump them.
Disable all built-in sounds from this character. Programmed sounds will still play. Note that other characters will still be able to detect this character's presence by listening.
Glide over the surface of any water. Turn this off to allow characters to fly down into the water.
Controls how far away other characters can hear this character. Doesn't change the actual sound the player hears.
Controls how far away this character can hear other characters. Doesn't change the actual sound the player hears.
True if bot is ghosted but still collidable with the environment.
Controls how strongly this bot kicks objects. A stronger kick will cause the object to fly farther.
Controls how quickly this bot can kick a second object after kicking the first one.
Scale the bot up (larger) or down (smaller). A scale of 1.0 is normal size.
When you see something, you remember it for a few seconds as though you can still see it.
Affects how bright the glow effect is for this character. Note that glowing characters do not normally cast light on other characters.
Make this object actually cast light on others when it's glowing, and set how strong the effect is.
Set how strongly the glow from this bot lights itself up.
When characters are programmed to wander, circle, or move away from something, this shows any barriers that are obstructing its path.
If this bot is using vision or hearing, shows which bots this bot can see and hear.
Shows the current programming page over the bot.
Currently not implemented.

Creates an invisible barrier around the edges of your world. This will prevent bots from falling off the edge of the world.
The Balloon, Cloud, Jet, Light, Saucer, Blimp, Wisp and Missile can go through the glass wall.
Displays a history of the people who have changed this world.

Allows you to control how the camera moves when your game is running.
The Fixed Position option keeps the camera from moving at all while your game is running. Useful for arcade style games that require an overhead view. Note that the view will be different on widescreen displays.
The Fixed Offset option keeps the camera a fixed distance and direction from whatever object the camera is following. This can be the cursor or a bot. Useful for sidescrollers.
The Free option is the default and lets the camera roam free unless a bot's programming tells the camera to be in first person or to follow it. If you're using fixed or offset camera, pressing the <X> button will let you set the position of the camera.

Controls where the camera is positioned when your game starts. To use, move the camera to where you want it to be when the game starts, open World Settings and check the box. If you later want to change the position you can press <x> which will be put into a mode which will let you freely align the camera to whatever position you need.
Controls how strongly the camera swings to be behind a user-controlled character.
Lets you hide the Compass which normally appears in the lower right hand corner of the screen. The compass is always shown during editing and is only hidden when you run your game.
Lets you hide the Resource Meter (thermometer) which normally appears on the right side of the screen. The Resource Meter is always shown during editing and is only hidden when you run your game.

Lets you turn off the resource limiting as shown by the Resource Meter (thermometer) which normally appears on the right side of the screen. With this option off you can add as much terrain and as many object to your world as you want. WARNING: Without this limit you may cause Kodu to run extremely slowly. You may also exceed your system's memory and cause Kodu to crash.
Controls the height of the waves when you have water in your world.
Controls how strongly the water distorts the view.
Choose a set of background colors for your world. Combine the Sky and Lighting settings to help create a mood for you game.

Choose a set of lights for your world. If you choose a dark lighting setup then it will only be dark when you run your game. During editing a brighter lighting setup will be used so you can still clearly see your world. Combine the Sky and Lighting settings to help create a mood for you game.
Controls the softest the breeze blows through the trees in game.
Controls the hardest the breeze blows through the trees in game.

Control how your game starts when you play it: "Nothing" just starts the game as normal, with no effect. "World Title" displays the name of the world for 3 seconds and then starts playing. "World Description" displays the name of the world and prompts the user to press <a> to start playing. This uses the description you provide when you save the game. "Countdown" displays a 3-2-1 countdown before the game begins. This is great for racing games.
When characters are following paths, this shows which waypoint each character is moving towards. Target goals show as wireframes and are colored the same as the character who is moving towards them
Shows the shapes that are used by bots and other objects to bump into each other and the ground.
If any bot is using vision or hearing, shows which bots they can see and hear.
Shows the current programming page for programmed bots.
Speed factor for terrain edits. Smaller is slower, bigger is faster.
Controls the volume of the UI sound effects such as menus and buttons.
Controls the volume of the effects in your game. This includes explosions, collisions and the sounds that the bots make.
Controls the volume of the background music you choose for your game.

Controls how prominent the display will be for scoring events of this color. Off: the score won’t be displayed at all. Quiet: the score will be displayed in the corner, but there will be no scoring effects. Loud: score events will animate from their location in the game to the scoreboard.

Controls whether a given score will be persisted during a NextLevel/PreviousLevel action. On: the score will be persisted and will maintain the same value when the new level loads Off: the score will be reset to zero when the new level loads
Shows/Hides on screen virtual controller.

Controls how the GUI buttons will display. Off: the button won’t be displayed at all. No Label: The button will be displayed and will have no text on it. Labeled: The button will be displayed along with some text to better identify the button.
Sets the level that will be loaded by the "Next Level" tile. Also enables the "Previous Level" tile from that level to return the player to the current level.
Raises the water under this object.
Lowers the water under this object.
Sets the water type under this object.
Allows you to turn off tool tips.

Allows you to turn off hints. Hints are displayed whenever the system detects a situation that might be causing a problem. When a hint is displayed, you are given the option of choosing to disable the hint.

Normally when the Gamepad Tool Menu is active, the background is blurred out and you can't move the camera around. By turning this option off, the camera will still be "live". However, you still must select a tool before interacting with the world. Turning this off also means that the left stick is now used to control the camera so you must use the DPad or the Triggers to select the tool you want.
This clears the 'disabled' flag on any hints you've previously chosen to disable so that they will appear again.
When enabled the current framerate (FPS) is shown in the lower left-hand corner of the screen.
Controls the amount of help text displayed in the upper left-hand corner of the screen.
Controls which language is used. Kodu's translations are done by our community. If you'd like to help translate Kodu into your language please email KoduSupport@microsoft.com for more information.
Make pushing the stick move the bot down.
Make pushing the stick left turn the bot toward the right.
Make pushing the stick forward pitch the camera up.
Make pushing the stick left rotate the camera to the right.

The term "overscan" refers to the amount of the rendered image that is cut off at the edges of the display. This amount depends on both the display device and the connection to the device. The slider allows you to control how far into the center of the screen the help displays are positioned. If they're being cut off on your display, make this value larger. On tube TVs usually 20% works best. On computer monitors you may be able to work with 0 or 5%. Experiment and use what looks best for you.
If set, other users will be able to add worlds to your download queue.
If set, worlds you download from other players will automatically be marked as shared, making them available for download in future sharing sessions.
In sharing sessions, automatically download worlds marked with the "Favorite" tag.
The range used by the Close By filter, used by the sight and hearing sensors. Units are in meters. For reference: A terrain tile is a half meter across.
The range used by the Far Away filter, used by the sight and hearing sensors. Units are in meters. For reference: A terrain tile is a half meter across.
If set, during startup Kodu will check to see if a newer version has been released.
If set, Kodu will send anonymous information to Microsoft about how you use Kodu. This information helps us improve Kodu.
If set, the next time Kodu is started, the introduction video will be played.

Normally, your Kodu Community web site login information will be forgotten when you exit Kodu. If this setting is turned on then we will try to allow your login to persist over multiple Kodu sessions.
This is an aid for people creating their own tutorials. When turned on and running a tutorial level this will display debug information overlayed on the screen.
